intro: Dipidax punctata, commonly known as the spotted bellflower, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, violet or blue flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and streambanks. Its leaves are lanceolate and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
